title-group.article-title: Flipped Classrooms and Finance—Is this a Better Way to Learn?

abstract.p: As expected, with the increased usage of technology in classrooms, professors have been exploring new ways of making use of classroom time, ways to encourage honesty in work, ways to bring remote classes of students together, and more. A movement started in a Colorado high school [Bergmann and Sams, 2007] has caught on at the higher education level. Flipped classrooms involve moving what would traditionally be considered lecture (normally delivered during formal class hours) into the out-of-classroom hours (typically the time that a student would have spent doing homework), and moving what used to be homework into the classroom, so that the instructor is supervising homework and group activity during what used to be the lecture period of time, and students are expected to listen to the lecture (typically pre-recorded by the instructor) outside of the class meeting time.
